questions.question_text: When threat hunting for outliers in Splunk, which of the following SPL pipelines would filter for users with over a thousand occurrences?

choices.B: | stats count by user | where count > 1000 | sort - count
choices.D: | stats count(user) | sort - count | where count > 1000

discussion.content: Someone please verify the accuracy of this answer

Answer - C. Annotations
Annotations in Splunk Enterprise Security allow correlation searches to be tagged with relevant frameworks, like NIST 800-171, CIS, or MITRE ATT&CK. This tagging provides context to the analyst, showing how specific searches align with these frameworks. It effectively maps correlation searches to compliance guidelines or security frameworks.

Framework mapping isn't an official Splunk Enterprise Security feature or term. The closest feature that performs this mapping function in Splunk is indeed Annotations.

So, C. Annotations is correct because it is the feature in Splunk Enterprise Security designed for mapping correlation searches to frameworks like NIST.

comments.content: where you sure about any of the questions?

questions.question_text:
The United States Department of Defense (DoD) requires all government contractors to provide adequate security safeguards referenced in National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) 800-171. All DoD contractors must continually reassess, monitor, and track compliance to be able to do business with the US government.
Which feature of Splunk Enterprise Security provides an analyst context for the correlation search mapping to the specific NIST guidelines?

An analyst is investigating the number of failed login attempts by IP address. Which SPL command can be used to create a temporary table containing the number of failed login attempts by IP address over a specific time period?

choices.B: index=security_logs eventtype=failed_login | transaction count as failed_attempts by src_ip | sort -failed_attempts
choices.A: index=security_logs eventtype=failed_login | eval count as failed_attempts by src_ip | sort -failed_attempts
choices.C: index=security_logs eventtype=failed_login | stats count as failed_attempts by src_ip | sort -failed_attempts
choices.D: index=security_logs eventtype=failed_login | sum count as failed_attempts by src_ip | sort -failed_attempts
